ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HDB FLATS IN OLDER HOUSING ESTATES
(Building of more)


    1. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development whether there are

Column: 664

plans to step up the building of more Housing and Development Board flats in older housing estates.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the older housing estates the hon. Member is referring to are, I presume, those mature estates in Ang Mo Kio, Bedok, Bishan, Bukit Merah, Geylang, Kallang/Whampoa, Queenstown and Toa Payoh, where HDB has occasionally offered new flats for sale. These housing estates are almost totally built-up, and the land still available for public housing is very limited. Any new flats which come up for sale are built on in-fill developments in isolated sites. Therefore, new flats can be built in these older estates only when suitable in-fill sites are available for development.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Sir, I understand there are residents who want to upgrade themselves and want to stay in the neighbourhood. Are there plans for decantation and the provision of opportunities for them to upgrade in the older city areas?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: HDB has a scheme which gives residents in the mature estates twice the priority for new flats in their estate compared to residents from outside the estate. But, as he knows, the number of applicants for flats in the mature estates is very large. So even though they have twice the probability they still end up with a fairly slim chance.

     Dr Vasoo: In the light that there are more demands for upgrading of flats by residents in the mature estates, are there other alternatives, besides the upgrading programme that is being proposed? Or would the upgrading programme be hastened in the older mature estates?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: The upgrading programme is targeted at the older estates. The sequence of the upgrading gives priority to those estates which are oldest. The Member can see that in the scheduling of the upgrading programme, we schedule those estates which are oldest first. That will be the main programme by which people staying in

Column: 665

mature estates will see their flats upgraded and enhanced in value. If they want to upgrade to a new and bigger flat, then they must apply for the new flats which are being built in their estate and although we give them priority, compared to non-residents, as I said, the demand is very, very high.

     Dr Vasoo: Sir, would there be plans to buy back older flats and provide people with alternatives to better upgraded flats in the near future?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: HDB is considering many schemes. If the Member has any suggestion on how such schemes can be implemented, we will be happy to listen to him.

     Dr Toh Keng Kiat (Nominated Member): Sir, may I ask the Minister whether there are any plans to demolish low-rise apartments and rebuild on the same site to maximise land use?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: As I said, HDB considers many possibilities and we will be happy to evaluate any new ideas that the Member may have.

Column: 665

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD FLATS
(Raising of ceiling limit for buyers who are co-owners of private residential properties)


    2. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board will, in the light of the recent escalation in property prices, reconsider raising the ceiling limit of $200,000 imposed on potential buyers of flats from the HDB, who are co-owners of private residential properties and whose interest in such properties is not more than 50% but exceeds the ceiling limit of $200,000.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang (for the Minister for National Development): The objective of providing public housing is to help Singaporeans who cannot afford private housing to secure affordable housing.

Column: 666

Eligibility conditions are imposed to ensure that only those in genuine need are allocated subsidised public housing.

    HDB, however, recognises that not all who own a share of a private property are able to afford private housing. This is especially so for properties acquired by way of gift or inheritance. Special consideration is therefore given to those who have an interest in a private residential property not exceeding $200,000 in value and holding more than 50% share to buy a flat directly from HDB.

    In 1989, HDB relaxed its rules to allow private property owners to buy HDB flats from the secondary market. With this relaxation, those who own a share in private properties exceeding the value of $200,000 can purchase a resale flat. In view of this, it is not necessary to review the current $200,000 limit on the value of the interest in the private properties for the purchase of flats directly from HDB.

Column: 666

PUBLICITY CAMPAIGN ON INVESTMENT IN SHARES


    3. Mr Chia Shi Teck asked the Minister for Finance if he will state (i) the reasons for the Government's publicity campaign to get Singaporeans to invest in shares; (ii) the target group it hopes to reach; and (iii) the cost and success of the campaign so far.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Singapore Telecom's (ST) listing in a few weeks' time will be the largest listing so far in Singapore. Through the ST listing, and the sale of Group A ST shares at a discount to citizens, the Government is promoting long-term, widespread share ownership. This will give Singaporeans a direct stake in the country's success, and enable them to share in its prosperity.

    Currently, out of 1.9 million adult Singaporeans, only 250,000 have ever owned shares. Of the 700,000 CPF members who qualify for the CPF Approved Investment Scheme, 120,000 have actually bought shares under the scheme. To promote widespread ownership, we need to raise the level of awareness and knowledge of shares among the general population. Hence the publicity campaign.

Column: 667



    The programme is targeted at the entire adult population of Singaporeans, especially those who are unfamiliar with shares. It has two objectives: general share education, putting across the basic facts about shares as a form of investment, the potential risks and rewards, and the mechanics of buying and selling shares; and specific information about ST's listing, especially the offer of Group A ST shares.

    The total cost of the public programme is estimated at $3.6 million. This is small compared to the magnitude of the education effort required, and to the size of the ST listing. As a percentage of the proceeds from the ST listing, it is less than the amount spent on similar public education programmes in other privatisations overseas, for instance, the British Telecom listing.

    Our surveys have shown a high level of awareness of and interest in the ST listing. Many of those surveyed have said they intend to buy ST shares, although we will not know how many actually do so until the actual offer. We should be able to achieve the target of doubling the present number of share owners in Singapore.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck (Nominated Member): Sir, it looks like the publicity is meant to get Singaporeans to invest in ST shares. Is that the case?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Yes, that is the primary reason although in the process there is a wider education programme which is linked to it, ie, to make people understand the purpose of shares and the risks involved. Having learned how to buy ST shares, there is also definitely the possibility that they will buy other shares which are more risky and they should know the consequences.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck: Would the Government openly tell Singaporeans to invest in proper blue chip shares in Singapore as 70% of daily trading are on Malaysian OTC shares and the lure of easy money may get Singaporeans burnt?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Singaporeans who use the CPF share programme are only allowed to buy trustee stocks. To that

Column: 668

extent, they are already limited in the range of shares they can buy. They are not allowed to use their CPF savings to buy shares on the Clob which are highly speculative, as the Member has said.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck: Sir, will this euphoria, when Singaporeans make money out of these shares, lead Singaporeans to think that this is an easy way to make money rather than to actually work?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: That is indeed a risk. But we cannot totally eliminate this risk and I am afraid that some people who have a stronger gambling instinct are likely to get burnt. I just hope that people will use their discretion and get burnt lightly before they learn a lesson.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck: The Minister has just said yesterday that the instinct in Singaporeans is that they would gamble and with this publicity for easy money, would it not aggravate the problem?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: The campaign is not to make easy money. It is to teach them to invest in blue chips like ST which is part of the Singapore economy. Our hope is that they will confine their purchases to the blue chips in companies like ST, SPH, SIA and so forth which are part of the Singapore economy, and not speculate on companies without any assets where they are likely to get burnt.

Column: 668

ANSWERS TO PARLIAMENTARY QUESTIONS
(Cost to taxpayers)


    4. Mr Koo Tsai Kee asked the Minister for Finance what is the cost taxpayers have to bear every time a question is filed and answered in Parliament.

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: The imputed cost of answering a question raised by an MP in Parliament is estimated to range from $500 to $1,300 depending on the complexity and nature of the questions asked. This imputed cost is not necessarily a real incremental cost that taxpayers have to pay as the preparation of responses to MPs' questions constitutes only a part of the duties of public officers.

Column: 669

In other words, the imputed cost may not be saved even if MPs ceased asking questions altogether.

    However, I should point out that every time a question is raised by a Member of Parliament, the Minister and public officers of the Ministry concerned do spend considerable time and effort to ensure a satisfactory answer is given. If the questions asked by MPs are pertinent and not frivolous, the time and effort spent is well worthwhile as they provide Ministries with an opportunity to explain and clarify Government policies or rules and regulations. On the other hand, if the questions asked are repetitious or of marginal public interest, the time and energies of public officers may be diverted from more urgent matters.

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Sir, will the Minister tell the House whether the price of democracy, ie, $500 to $1,300, is high or low for each question filed in Parliament?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: As I said, it is not a real cost in the sense that you cannot remove it by not asking questions. I am merely making an appeal that if you ask questions, make sure that the questions are relevant, in which case the Government would be very happy to respond. In other words, it is well worth it.

Column: 669

NATIONAL UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL
(Expansion plans)


    5. Mr Loh Meng See asked the Minister for Health whether there are plans to expand the National University Hospital and, if so, whether he will include Class C wards in the plans.

     The Minister for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, implementation of the National University Hospital (NUH) Phase III expansion project has started. It will introduce 112 C Class beds to the current bed complement, as well as expand Class A and B1 facilities by 50 and 48 beds respectively.

    Phase III will involve the construction of a new Tower block with a podium as well

Column: 670

as conversion work in the existing buildings. When completed, NUH will have a total of 991 beds, compared to the current 702. The heavily subsidised B2 and C beds will form 60% of the bed complement.

    In addition to the new wards, Phase III will also house a new Day Surgery Complex with 28 beds and five operating theatres. Specialist Outpatient Clinics for Eye, ENT and surgical disciplines together with three specialised service centres, namely, oncology, endoscopy and renal medicine, will also be located in the building.

    The project is expected to be completed by 1997 at an estimated cost of $130 million.

     Mr Loh Meng See (Kampong Glam GRC): Sir, will there be any increase in the number of beds in the intensive care wards in the expanded hospital? Or will the number be the same?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: The number of ICU beds in NUH will increase by 15 with the expansion.

Column: 670

POLYCLINIC MEDICAL CENTRE AT YISHUN CENTRAL
(Increase in medical charges)


    6. Mr Cheo Chai Chen asked the Minister for Health whether medical charges at the new polyclinic at Yishun Central, opposite Block 647, will increase when it becomes a medical centre; and whether he will confirm that the medical centre will start operating in January 1994.

     The Minister of State for Health (Dr Aline K. Wong) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Yishun Medical Centre will be leased out to private medical practitioners who will determine their own charges to the patients. Such charges may vary according to the types of services rendered, the experience and qualifications of the doctors, and so on. My Ministry will not be controlling their charges.

    The Centre is scheduled to start operating in March 1994.

Column: 671



     Mr Cheo Chai Chen (Nee Soon Central): Sir, can the Minister tell me what types of services will be provided in this medical centre?

     Dr Aline Wong: In this medical centre, there will be 14 clinical suites which may house GP clinics, specialist clinics and dental clinics, five retail suites which will be for health related retail services, one pharmacy, one X-ray suite and one clinical laboratory.

Column: 671

EDUCATION FOR CHILDREN OF SINGAPOREANS
WORKING OR DOING BUSINESS OVERSEAS


    The following Question stood in the name of Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon -

    7. To ask the Minister for Education, in view of the Government's policy of encouraging more Singaporeans to work or do business overseas, what are his plans for the education of the children of these Singaporeans and whether the plans will include having more boarding schools for these children who stay behind in Singapore.

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Question No. 7, Sir.

     The Minister of State for Education (Dr Ker Sin Tze) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, Singaporeans working overseas are generally able to send their children to the international schools at their places of work. Nevertheless, with the increasing number of Singaporeans venturing overseas, the Ministry will consider setting up Singapore-styled schools at the primary level in places where there is a critical mass of Singapore families. Such a school was set up in Hong Kong in 1991 for the 6,000-strong Singaporean community there. In places where there is no critical mass of Singaporeans, the Ministry may set up language tuition centres if there is sufficient demand for instruction in the mother tongue.

    Singaporeans venturing overseas who want their children to continue schooling in Singapore can place them in our student hostels and a few privately-run hostels. The total capacity of all these hostels is about 1,600. The Ministry has

Column: 672

recently approved the building of 800 more places in boarding schools and hostels which should be ready by 1995 to cater to the anticipated increase in demand by Singaporean parents.

Column: 672

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND ACCOUNTS OF NON-WORKING PERSONS
(Contributions from working relatives)


    8. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Minister for Labour if he will allow regular contributions from working relatives to newly-opened Central Provident Fund accounts of non-working persons.

     The Minister for Labour (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Mr Speaker, Sir, the CPF Board has all along welcomed people who wish to make contributions to the CPF accounts of non-working relatives. Such accounts can be opened at any of the Board's offices. Contributions can be made in cheque, cash or through NETS at the Board's main office or any post office, or in cheque or through NETS at the Board's branch offices.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin (Nominated Member): Sir, is there any specified minimum amount? Or would the Ministry prefer a minimum amount? Otherwise, there may be a lot of work handled by the Board if small amounts of cheques are sent in.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: The Board does not have a minimum amount requirement at the moment. So far, I think not that many people are doing so. We will be prepared to set a minimum contribution if in fact more and more people are coming forward to make such voluntary contributions on behalf of their non-working relatives. I am prepared to review the condition in the light of experience.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Sir, in view of the fact that not many people are making use of this, would it be possible for the Ministry to make it better known so that more people could make use of it?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have no objection to doing that. I will ask the CPF Board to look into how it could widely publicise this information that CPF

Column: 673

members or any Singaporean are welcome to make voluntary contribution to the CPF account of their non-working relatives.

Column: 673

MEASURES TO ENSURE MOTORISTS GIVE WAY TO EMERGENCY VEHICLES


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Robert Chua Teck Chew -

    9. To ask the Minister for Home Affairs what measures are being taken to ensure that motorists on the road give way immediately to ambulances, fire engines and other emergency vehicles which are in the course of handling emergencies.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck: Question No. 9, Sir.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) responds to about 5,000 ambulance calls and 400 fire calls every month. The SCDF observes that instances of motorists failing to give way to our emergency vehicles are relatively few. The problem is therefore not serious.

    At present, there is adequate legislation to deal with such motorists. Under the Road Traffic Act, all traffic, on the approach of any emergency vehicle, is required to draw in as close as possible to the edge of the road to allow a clear passage for the vehicle. A motorist who fails to give way can be fined up to $1,000 or be imprisoned for a term not exceeding three months. In the case of a second or subsequent offence, the maximum fine and prison term are $2,000 and six months respectively. Every offence also carries four demerit points.

    As part of Police enforcement action, a driver of an emergency vehicle may lodge a police report against any motorist who fails to give way to his vehicle. In 1992, five motorists were booked for such an offence. In 1993, to-date, one motorist has been booked.

    The SCDF is constantly improving its emergency services. For example, it has

Column: 674

introduced the Fast Response Medic (FRM) Scheme where medics on motorcycles are despatched to attend to road accident victims ahead of ambulances. Even then, the Ministry of Home Affairs will continue its efforts to educate motorists on giving way to emergency vehicles. An instance is the recent Traffic Police Road Courtesy Campaign where this message was reinforced.

Column: 674

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Number and profile of flats revested)


    10. Dr Michael Lim Chun Leng asked the Minister for National Development what is the number and profile of Housing and Development Board flats that were revested by the HDB from 1988 to 1992 because of inability to continue with mortgage loan repayments.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, between 1988 and 1992, action was taken to revest the titles of 2,269 flats because the owners were unable to continue with their mortgage loan repayment. The HDB examines each case carefully and offers assistance to the owners wherever possible. For example, depending on the circumstances of each case, HDB will, as far as possible, allow the owners with genuine financial difficulties to defer payment of their instalments for at least six months, or reschedule their loan repayment period up to a maximum of 25 years, or opt to pay the instalments under the easy repayment scheme such as paying 75% of the normal monthly instalment for the first five years.

    Eventually, of the initial 2,269 flats, HDB only took possession of 366 flats as a last resort. Even for these 366 cases, HDB continued to render assistance by offering rental housing. About 90% of them took up the offer. The rest chose to move in with their relatives or friends.

    The number of flats recovered is only about 0.1% of the number of flats under each flat type.

     Dr Michael Lim Chun Leng (Cheng San GRC): Sir, can the Minister clarify what is

Column: 675

the profile of the flats? Are they three-roomers mainly or also four-roomers and five-roomers?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Out of the 366 flats that were finally taken back, the majority were three-roomers which reflect the flat profile of the existing flats. There are cases of four-roomers, five-roomers and executive flats being revested.

     Dr Michael Lim Chun Leng: What is the period of occupancy by these residents before they default on repayment? Can the Minister either give a range or a mean or median period?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: The cases cover the entire range of HDB flat owners. Some people fall into arrears very early in their mortgage payments. Some have temporary financial difficulties and then fall into arrears. And despite the rescheduling of the loan, they cannot catch up with the repayment of the arrears and therefore have to give up the flat. Some have upgraded and find that they have upgraded beyond their means and then they have to give up their flat and downgrade. So it covers a wide range of cases.

     Dr Michael Lim Chun Leng: Are there any preventive measures that are taken by the Ministry to actually prevent such revestment procedures from being undertaken because the revestment process is not only socially very traumatic for the family but also results in a net loss for the family? If the Ministry can study the household income profiles of these families, then perhaps there may be a certain household income which would alert the officials and these families can be specially counselled in terms of the repayment schedules and in terms of the downpayment, so that they will not have their flat revested, say, within a year of their buying the flat.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Let me explain to the Member that buying of HDB flats varies according to the many situations. Many home owners may not have CPF but they are able, and they continue to be able, to pay their mortgage payments through cash. If you look at their declared income or their CPF accounts, bona fide, they may not seem to be in a position to buy a

Column: 676

5-room flat. But I can assure you that many thousands of them continue to buy 5-room flats and continue to service their loans. There are many people who, on the basis of their income statement and their CPF, look able to afford a 4-room flat or 5-room flat, but because of poor financial management - they gamble, they drink, they squander away their money - they fall into arrears. There are many such cases. In the end, I think it is best that individual home owners decide for themselves what flat they are able to afford and which type of flat they should invest in. It is very difficult for Government to set up hurdles and say, "If you don't have such an income, you are not allowed to buy a 5-room flat."

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Sir, would the Minister confirm that when the flat is revested or compulsorily acquired, the owners are compensated at the original price while the HDB then sells the flat later on at the posted price? Is that true?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: The price at which the HDB acquires the flat depends on the period of occupation. If the owner has occupied the flat for more than five years, HDB will advise the owner to sell the flat in the resale market and pay back the arrears. That is the normal route most owners will take when they realise that they cannot continue to service the loan for such a big flat. And if they have stayed in it for more than five years, then they will sell it in the open market and pay the arrears. For flats which are less than five years, then HDB acquires it based on the original purchase price.

     Dr Michael Lim Chun Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Ministry consider looking at the 366 flats that were revested and actually study the income profile of these families and perhaps that would give them an idea of the type of families that are likely to run into these problems? I think my main concern is those families who do not actually have the money to purchase the flat but went ahead without sound advice. Perhaps HDB could help out by providing some financial advice on some mortgage loan schedules before they sign to purchase the flat. If they can have a study of the household income

Column: 677

profile of these families, perhaps there may be an income limit in which it will alert the officials to these types of families.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: As I have already explained to the hon. Member, HDB has studied the income profile of these cases. We have been in this business for 30 years. There is no set pattern of people who can afford or cannot afford. Many of them were able to afford in the beginning. They make wrong career decisions, business decisions, they fall into arrears. Many people, on paper, would not be able to afford and HDB will advise them not to buy. I think they will all come to the MP and complain. It is their own business how they manage their funds. Many have got other avenues of income. They may not have a declared income or may not have CPF, but they all seem to be able to buy a 4-room or 5-room flat quite comfortably and service their loans.     Sir, in the Committee's key findings, it is noted that the proportion of households with monthly incomes of $4,000 and above rose from 6.3% in 1980 to 24% in 1990, and households earning less than $1,000 per month fell from 48% to 16%. Sir, whilst more households have higher earnings now than 1980 to somewhat offset the increase in cost over the same period, my concern is for the 16% of households whose family incomes remain at less than $1,000 per month. Cost increases over the last 10 years have been considerable. $1,000 may not be able to buy the same basket of goods today. Thus, to these 16% whose family incomes

    The Committee has pointed out that the impact and the severity of certain cost increases could have been ameliorated. It has identified simultaneous cost adjustments after the last recession as one cause. The solution is simple, as the Committee has noted: coordinate fee increases, if they really cannot be absorbed by the Government, and introduce them gradually over a period of time. But more importantly, Sir, give the people a choice. I think this recommendation of giving Singaporeans a choice echoes the inner voices of many, especially those in the lower income group.

    Sir, for a choice to be real and choosable, I would urge the Government to constantly review the standard of services provided, such as in health care and education, and if necessary, to adjust the subsidies to keep pace with cost increases so that the quality of service will not suffer, and the services remain affordable. If the choices are provided by statutory boards, the MRT and the bus companies, make sure there are enough alternatives for the people to choose from. Thus, while there are people who like to live in bigger and even self-designed flats

    Similarly, when a bus commuter could save 60 cents or more a day taking a non-airconditioned bus to work, we should give him the choice, and ensure that there are enough non-air-conditioned buses plying the route.

    Sir, the Government has always wanted Singaporeans to have a share of Singapore, to be part of its prosperity and success. Thus, instead of restricting Singaporeans to rent a piece of Singapore, whether a flat, a shophouse, or even a hawker stall, we encourage ownership. Unfortunately, the best approach to determining the price of a piece of valuable Singapore is through the tender system. This policy is inherently correct and is for the benefit of Singaporeans because property prices tend to rise in the long run. But the immediate impact could always be counter-objective. Sir, this is because land is scarce in Singapore. In the midst of a booming economy now, exacerbated by the kiasu mentality of some Singaporeans, bid prices have sky-rocketed. The result: successful property developers, shopkeepers and stallholders inevitably will have to pass the high bid costs down to the consumers in order to survive. And consumers will have to pay more, resulting in higher costs of living.

    Sir, whilst the policy of allowing Singaporeans to own Singapore is laudable, the timing of tendering exercises is very important. Just as the bad coordination of bus fare and MRT fare and health care cost increases have upset some Singaporeans in the past, will not the sudden rush-in of tendering for almost everything - COE, share prices, land, shophouses - be cause and reason enough for another disenchantment?
